description.narrative: Improved evidence based policies to address the causes of exclusion of boys and girls, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children (Covid), Early Childhood Development, Education â€“ General, Evaluation And Research, Health â€“ General, Hiv Prevention, Immunization, Nutrition â€“ General, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Social Exclusion â€“ Data And Evidence, Social Protection, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, the most excluded boys and girls benefit from enhanced and inclusive public policies and services and actively participate in decision making processes.*Children most expected to benefit: Afro-descendant, Quilombolas, indigenous people, children with disabilities, with HIV/AIDS, in rural areas and in vulnerable urban territories, LGBT youth.

sector.narrative: Child poverty analysis towards policy change (Profiling, mapping and identifying drivers of multi-dimensional and monetary poverty of children, modelling and simulation of policy options)

Contributing to policies reducing child poverty: Poverty reduction strategies, national development plans, engagement with ministries, parliament, international donor and financial organizations, civil society organizations)
Evaluation innovation learning, uptake and partnerships for evaluation

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Improved evidence based policies to address the causes of exclusion of boys and girls

description.narrative: In 2019 a new PF4C agenda was established with key strategic allies, including the Ministry of Economy, sub-national government entities, research institutes and the public attorney's office, all of whom are working on the analysis of public spending for children. As a key result, those partners conformed a network, paving the way for the most complete identification of child-related budget ever done in Brazil. Furthermore, to support the humanitarian response, a diagnostic was carried out on social protection response for Venezuelan migrants. Advocacy efforts also led way for strengthened and more structured partnerships between UNICEF and the Brazilian legislative branch. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:06/02/2020

title.narrative: National evidence generated on relevant child focused social policy topics
